metadata.name: A Gift of Nature #115
metadata.description:
Can nature really be a gift if it isn't ours to give?
Do we feel the need to bind it close in the ways of old to live?
If a gift was given would all be forgiven, a place of harmony now we can live in?

/*./*..\*./*..\*../*./*..\*./*..\*.

A gift of nature, sort of. As natural as a digital gift can be. It is a gen art token of my gratitude you might say. It is the younger sibling of "The Spectrum of Nature". 

This is a gift from me to you, a gift of nature that pulls you through. 

/*./*..\*./*..\*../*./*..\*./*..\*.

To know more about the concept and technicalities of this piece, see the fxtext article “The spectrum of nature - a short making of”. However, feel free to skip the article.

/*./*..\*./*..\*../*./*..\*./*..\*.

Basic info:
The initial render will be 1000px wide and 1000px high. With the ability to scale this up (see below).

The piece uses WebGL, so will perform much better with a graphics card. A faster computer will obviously be better, though I've done my very best to make it fast and efficient for any old laptop. My hope is that you will find the render process quick and enjoyable for the amount of detail that’s present.

/*./*..\*./*..\*../*./*..\*./*..\*.

Controls:
Press the [s] key to save the initial render. You will need to wait a few seconds after all the elements have stopped loading. For the [s] key to work you may need to open in a new tab. But can right click save otherwise.

Larger sizes:
Press the [2-9] keys to save a resolution of that key size. So [2] saves a 2000x2000 size image, [9] saves a 9000x9000 size image etc. Unless you are making some very large prints you probably won’t need more than 4k (even 2-3k is big). Though the option is there.

There may be slight variations in the textures for the larger renders, this is because the shader code has to redraw the textures at the higher pixel resolution, and getting the textures where they sit is more of an art than a science. All the elements remain exact however.

/*./*..\*./*..\*../*./*..\*./*..\*.

Made with javascript and some small extra code:
A palette creator by @nathansonic
Noisejs - github.com/josephg/noisejs - Perlin noise generator
Twgl - github.com/greggman/twgl.js - A small webGL helper.

metadata.name: STRUCTURES #250
metadata.description:
STRUCTURES

What color do things look when you're happy?

First of all I want to dedicate this collection to all the people who paint their emotions with color, who through a chromatic range, are capable of feeling a universe of sensations most of the time inexplicable.....

 I am fascinated by how generative art creates a perfect symbiosis between art and technology, allowing through a set of algorithmic rules to give rise to compositions where shapes and colors coexist in balance, harmonized with each other that give rise to new creations.

This collection is designed to be self-contained and limited, recreating the view from different angles and phases of the day that can lead to disparate interpretations of a piece.

My work as a visual artist explores elements such as randomness and chance of linear formations and geometric gradients that broaden the spectrum to increasingly new concepts that I definitely want to explore.

I continually wonder what the geometric patterns that will emerge from my sensibility will be like and will give rise to new collections like this one, which is why I continue to investigate techniques and shapes while having fun.

"A painting is not the image of an experience, but it is the experience." Mark Rothk

metadata.name: Ode to Pollock #110
metadata.description:
This artwork was inspired by Jackson Pollock's abstract style, and particularly by his drip technique.

The best results are from 1000x1000 and above.

This work created using p5.js and ❤

metadata.name: Less Mess #71
metadata.description:
When observing the universe we can see both order and chaos, "Less Mess" is the relationship between those two forces. Randomness and order are everywhere, in each iteration of nature we can see both forces taking place. Each matter observed by us is made from ordered atoms, but each matter in its base is random and unique.

This work evolved from a simple grid. While it started as a very ordered grid, I pushed as hard as possible to make it messy and randomly beautiful. After applying a lot of mess, it becomes very busy and the order was gone. When the mess was all over the place, I started to reduce it, step by step, to bring the harmony back.

The best results are from 1000x1000 and above.

This work was created using p5.js and ❤

Twitter: @AsafSlook
Instagram: @asaf_slook

metadata.name: CR Art Sessions //2 #159
metadata.description:
Grayscale, Hold the Line, and Mondrian walk into a bar. The bartender looks up and says, "What is this, some kind of art project?"

Grayscale responds, "No, we're just here for a drink."

Hold the Line adds, "But we can definitely add some color to the place if you want."

Mondrian chimes in, "I prefer to keep things simple and stick to the basics."

The bartender shakes his head and says, "I'll be the judge of that. What can I get you all?"

Grayscale orders a Guinness, Hold the Line asks for a gin and tonic, and Mondrian asks for a glass of white wine.

The bartender serves up the drinks and says, "That will be $15.50, please."

Grayscale pulls out a twenty-dollar bill and hands it to the bartender, saying, "Keep the change."

The bartender thanks him and says, "Thanks, Grayscale. You always know how to liven up the place."

Hold the Line raises his glass and says, "Cheers to that!"

Mondrian nods and clinks glasses with the others, and the three of them enjoy their drinks and the rest of their evening at the bar.

-----

Press "e" to save a png (3240*4500 or 4500*3240 px) while in live mode.

-----

Artwork by @cristianrohr (2022)

Made with P5js and <3.

metadata.name: coral reef #41
metadata.description:
The coral reef is the magic of the sea, it is a small natural wonder that we must preserve.
They are embraced by the mystery and beauty of the water world.

Artwork creates relief on patchwork backgrounds. Each piece creates a unique place with a unique tone, or what I consider a unique time of the day.

metadata.name: Glitchy Masks #11
metadata.description:
A big thank you to Aleksandra from https://www.fxhash.xyz/u/Aleksandra for their assistance with the code!

In this project, I explored the concept of randomness and was pleasantly surprised by the results. After a few iterations, masks began to emerge. I added a mirroring effect to enhance the visual and added eyes for added realism. The end result is a series of intriguing masks, created through the use of randomness and artistic experimentation.

To save your canvas, simply press S.

For more information and to stay up to date with my work, follow me on Twitter at @lomzart or visit my portfolio website at lomz.net. Thank you for your interest!

metadata.name: Splinter #200
metadata.description:
This release marks my first anniversary on the fx(hash) platform! I want to extend a huge thank you to everyone for a fantastic year, and I'm looking forward to many more in the generative-art world!

The basic algorithm is an evolution of the one I used in my first release, Raked Strokes. Instead of mimicking a brush with parallel segments, I'm using perpendicular line segments to define the overall abstract shape and then drawing each line in a simulated media. This approach blends my first attempts at natural media with everything I've learned in the past year.

Viewing in desktop Chrome is recommended for the best results.
Press 's' to save a screenshot. The image size is 2357x3000px
Press 'p' to pause/resume during drawing.

Features
- Base path shape: line, circle, diamond, or rectangle
- Elements defining the spacing and orientation of the line segments
- The base path painted in the background
- Monochrome, dark background, and selection of palettes
- Ink pen styling: thickness, quality, and background blocking
- Paint styling: color distribution, quality
- Shapes: triangle, polygons, criteria for insertion
- Shapes overdrawing: outlines or perpendicular segments

Copyright (c) 2022 Matt Perkins, hello@mattperkins.me, @nudoru on Twitter. Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, see LICENSE.txt for more information.

metadata.name: tile #26
metadata.description:
I started GenArt about the same time fxhash came out.
I have made many GenArt by tiling since then. Remembering that origin, I created this work.

#fxhashturnsone

metadata.name: The Spectrum Of Nature #202
metadata.description:
*\_../*`¬-’\/*`¬’’¬`*\/’-¬`*\.._/*

Nature, nature, evolving might… Silent inventor, always right.
Where is the edge of nature and where do we begin?  
What is of nature and what is of man? 
Isn't everything made by nature's hands?

To know more about the concept and technicalities of this piece, see the fxtext article “The spectrum of nature - a short making of”. Link at the bottom. If you’d rather just ignore my personal meaning, feel free to skip the article. 

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\

Basic info:
The piece comes in possible portrait or landscape versions. Both have a relative size of 1 by 1.5. So the initial render will be 1000px wide and 1500px high for portrait. And 1500x1000 for landscape. With the ability to scale this up (see below).

The piece uses WebGL, so will perform much better with a graphics card. A faster computer will obviously be better, though I've done my very best to make it fast and efficient for any old laptop. My hope is that you will find the render process quick and enjoyable for the amount of detail that’s present. 

../’`*’`\../’`*’`\../’`*’`\../’`*’`\../’`*’`\..

Controls:
Press the [s] key to save the initial render. You will need to wait a few seconds after all the elements have stopped loading. A box will pop up in the top left saying “done” for 4 seconds when it’s ready. For the [s] key to work you may need to open in a new tab. But can right click save otherwise.

Larger sizes:
Press the [2-9] keys to save a resolution of that key size. So [2] saves a 2000x3000 size image, [9] saves a 9000x13500 size image etc. Unless you are making some very large prints you probably won’t need more than 4k (even 2-3k is big). Though the option is there. 

There may be slight variations in the textures for the larger renders, this is because the shader code has to redraw the textures at the higher pixel resolution, and getting the textures where they sit is more of an art than a science. All the elements remain exact however. 

/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*

Made with javascript and some small extra code:
A palette creator by @nathansonic
Noisejs - github.com/josephg/noisejs - Perlin noise generator
Twgl - github.com/greggman/twgl.js - A small webGL helper.

metadata.name: Artifice #168
metadata.description:
This series is is about playful obfuscation.

The fxtext article linked on the main profect goes more in-depth into what is meant by that, as well as the events that led to this collection.

5640 bytes of Vanilla JS with no libraries. Palettes make up a third of the code.

In live mode:
‘S’ : save as png (3000 × 3600)
’V’ : save as svg (without grain)

URL params in live mode:
‘g=n’ : no grain
‘g=p’ : paper grain
‘h=t’ : high resolution mode, 9000 ×10600 (Chrome only, and may take a moment)

For example, if you wanted paper grain in high resolution, append “&g=p&h=t” to the url in live mode.

After rendering with these params, tapping 'P' will then save a png with those settings applied.

metadata.description:
glitch universe of  skull monster devil pirate   punk robot / (s

metadata.name: Collapse #70
metadata.description:
The Impossibility of Representing Something Spherical Flat

A sphere collapses to a flat plane, revealing the transformations and stretching required for such an operation. How to represent something spherical flat? How to see what's not there, or how to see it differently? 

Released on the occasion of the Tribute to Herbert W. Franke.  
50% of the primary sales will be donated to the Foundation Herbert W. Franke.

metadata.name: outside.views #81
metadata.description: Generative art by Mark Knol (@mknol)

metadata.name: Hydro Gen #43
metadata.description:
Against the backdrop of texts about valuing water, Hydro Gen charts the ecological devastation and eventual revival of the Tisza river following what has been called one of the gravest environmental disasters in central Europe since Chernobyl.

Nature and humans here are bound within a single frame — havoc in the ecological system activates the breakdown of meaning in the human signifying system of language, but hidden in the wave of ecological disaster is a (re)generative love poem to water that bears witness to its multifaceted beauty and power. A second poem is generated as a soundtrack based on the displayed background text.

- - - - - CLICK TO START SOUND - - - - -

Hydro Gen is a collaborative work conceptualized and developed over the course of one week as part of NFT DEB Generative Dimensions 2022 Hackathon and Conference.

Kalen Iwamoto, lead artist, director

Vitalii Shumanskyi, lead programmer

Nayven Vignette, audio programmer

Tamás Béke, data analysis and visualization

metadata.name: Broken Symmetries #2/3 #11
metadata.description:
"It was the best of times, it was the worst of times, it was the age of wisdom, it was the age of foolishness, it was the epoch of belief, it was the epoch of incredulity, it was the season of Light, it was the season of Darkness, it was the spring of hope, it was the winter of despair, we had everything before us, we had nothing before us..."
Charles Dickens

This piece is the secon in a planed series of three intended as studies on composition.

It is built entirely on thi.ng/umbrella libraries and template:

https://github.com/thi-ng/fxhash-tpl

Keyboard shortcuts

- 1 : render @ original resolution
- 2 : render @ 2 x resolution
- 4 : render @ 4 x resolution
- x : download canvas as PNG @ current resolution
- s : download canvas as SVG @ current resolution; This can be used with a plotter.

metadata.name: EDDY #99
metadata.description:
An eddy is a circular movement of water counter to a main current. It reminds me of innovations in art, like a small countercurrent to the mainstream, surfacing new techniques and aesthetics. 

I hope that EDDY will brighten your days with its playful swirl of colors, inspired by the sea, the sky, the birds, and post-impressionist paintings.

Keyboard Controls:
[F] Fill the window.
[S] Save the current view in live mode as an image (default 1125x1500px).
[1] [2] [4] [6] Change resolution, 1.5K to 9K.
[R] Reverse course.

Made with p5js and shaders.

Created by elsif, 2022.12.

metadata.name: Glitchy Masks #13
metadata.description:
A big thank you to Aleksandra from https://www.fxhash.xyz/u/Aleksandra for their assistance with the code!

In this project, I explored the concept of randomness and was pleasantly surprised by the results. After a few iterations, masks began to emerge. I added a mirroring effect to enhance the visual and added eyes for added realism. The end result is a series of intriguing masks, created through the use of randomness and artistic experimentation.

To save your canvas, simply press S.

For more information and to stay up to date with my work, follow me on Twitter at @lomzart or visit my portfolio website at lomz.net. Thank you for your interest!
